Mucous membrane, Fibrous layer, Squamous epithelium

questions.text: A medical student is studying the anatomy of the ear and learns about the layers of the tympanic membrane (TM). Which of the following correctly lists the layers of the TM from outermost to innermost?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squamous Epithelium, Fibrous layer, Mucous membrane

 

Option A. 

 

The Tympanic membrane is composed of three layers.

 

  • The outermost layer is Squamous Epithelium (Ectodermal derivative), which is continuous with the skin of the external auditory canal.
  • The middle layer is a Fibrous layer (Mesodermal derivative), providing the TM with its strength and elasticity.
  • The innermost layer is a mucous membrane (Endodermal derivative), continuous with the lining of the middle ear cavity.

 

This arrangement (A) is the correct description of the layers of the TM. Also note that the 3 layers of tympanic membrane are developed from 3 embryonic germ layers.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. This option incorrectly lists the layers in reverse order.

 

Option C. This option incorrectly orders the layers, placing the fibrous layer first.

 

Option D. This option also incorrectly lists the stratified squamous epithelium and mucous membrane, reversing their positions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anatomical layering of the tympanic membrane consists of an outer stratified squamous epithelial layer, a middle fibrous layer, and an inner mucous membrane layer. This knowledge is important for understanding various ear pathologies and their treatments.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg3

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with pain localized to his left ear. There is no history of trauma or infection. An ENT specialist notes that the pain could be due to neuralgia involving a specific nerve plexus within the middle ear. Which nerve plexus is most likely involved in mediating this patient's ear pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tympanic Plexus

 

Option A. 

 

The tympanic plexus is a network of nerves found on the medial wall of the middle ear. It is formed by the tympanic branch (Jacobson’s nerve) of the Glossopharyngeal Nerve (CN IX) and provides sensory innervation to the mucosa of the middle ear, mastoid air cells, and part of the tympanic membrane. Neuralgia involving this plexus can manifest as ear pain without any apparent external or middle ear pathology.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The carotid plexus is a network of sympathetic nerves surrounding the carotid artery and is not primarily involved in sensory innervation of the ear.

 

Option C. The cervical plexus provides sensory and motor innervation to structures in the neck, but it does not directly innervate the middle ear or tympanic membrane to a significant extent.

 

Option D. The pharyngeal plexus is primarily involved in innervating the pharynx and does not play a major role in sensory innervation of the ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tympanic plexus, primarily formed by the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, provides sensory innervation to the middle ear and can be involved in ear pain syndromes such as neuralgia.

 

Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg8

questions.text: A patient develops sweating and flushing over the cheek while eating, following parotid gland surgery. Frey’s syndrome is suspected. Which of the following nerves is involved in the aberrant reinnervation responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auriculotemporal nerve

 

  • Final carrier of secretomotor fibres to parotid; responsible for Frey’s syndrome when misdirected.

 

Frey’s syndrome (gustatory sweating) occurs due to:

 

  • Aberrant regeneration of auriculotemporal nerve fibres after parotid gland surgery or trauma.
  • Parasympathetic secretomotor fibres (originally destined for the parotid gland) regenerate incorrectly and innervate sweat glands of the overlying skin.
  • As a result, sweating and flushing occur over the parotid region while eating (gustatory stimulus).

 

The auriculotemporal nerve:

 

  • Is a branch of mandibular nerve (V3)
  • Carries postganglionic parasympathetic fibres from the otic ganglion to the parotid gland
  • Final step of the tympanic plexus → lesser petrosal → otic ganglion → auriculotemporal → parotid pathway

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chorda tympani: Carries secretomotor fibres to submandibular and sublingual glands, not parotid.

 

Option C. Greater auricular nerve: Supplies cutaneous sensation over parotid region but is not involved in salivation.

 

Option D. Nerve to mylohyoid: Motor branch to mylohyoid and anterior belly of digastric; no secretomotor role.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frey’s syndrome results from aberrant regeneration of auriculotemporal nerve fibres that originally carried secretomotor supply to the parotid gland.

 

Parasympathetic pathway to the parotid gland :-

 

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 8

choices.text: A patient with true unilateral deafness hears sound only in the affected ear when both ears are stimulated
A malingerer will deny hearing any sound when the stimulus is stronger in the "deaf" ear and weaker in the normal ear
The test is used to confirm bilateral conductive hearing loss using tuning forks of different frequencies
A positive Stenger test confirms the diagnosis of sensorineural hearing loss in both ears

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the principle and interpretation of the Stenger test in a patient suspected of feigning unilateral hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A malingerer will deny hearing any sound when the stimulus is stronger in the "deaf" ear and weaker in the normal ear

 

Malingerer denies hearing when louder sound is in feigned deaf ear – Correct

 

Stenger test is a behavioral test used to detect non-organic or feigned unilateral hearing loss. It works on the Stenger principle:

 

When two tones of the same frequency but different intensities are presented simultaneously to both ears, the patient only perceives the louder tone.

 

How the test works:

 

  • Start by presenting equal-frequency sounds (via tuning forks or audiometer) to both ears.
  • Then move the sound closer to the side of the claimed deafness (i.e., make the sound louder in the "deaf" ear).
  • If the patient is truly deaf, they will continue to hear the tone in the normal ear.
  • If the patient is malingering, the louder sound in the "deaf" ear suppresses the softer one in the normal ear (per the Stenger principle), but the patient claims not to hear anything at all, revealing the deception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A patient with true unilateral deafness hears sound only in the affected ear when both ears are stimulated: Incorrect. A truly deaf ear won’t perceive sound; patient hears via normal ear.

 

Option C. The test is used to confirm bilateral conductive hearing loss using tuning forks of different frequencies: Stenger test is not diagnostic for bilateral conductive hearing loss.

 

Option D. A positive Stenger test confirms the diagnosis of sensorineural hearing loss in both ears: The test does not confirm SNHL in both ears; it's used for unilateral malingering.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Stenger test is used to detect unilateral malingering; if a patient denies hearing when a louder tone is presented to the "deaf" ear, it indicates feigned hearing loss (positive Stenger test).

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 22

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset vertigo, nausea, and hearing loss in his right ear following a deep scuba diving session earlier in the day. He denies any recent upper respiratory infections, otalgia, or discharge from the ear. On examination, you note horizontal nystagmus and a negative Rinne test on the affected side. The tympanic membrane is intact without signs of inflammation or effusion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perilymph fistula

 

Option C.

 

In this scenario, the sudden onset of symptoms following a pressure-altering event (scuba diving), combined with hearing loss and vertigo without any signs of middle ear infection or inflammation, points towards a perilymph fistula. Diagnosis can be challenging and often relies on clinical presentation and history, as physical exam findings can be subtle or nonspecific.

 

Perilymph fistula is a condition where there is an abnormal communication between the perilymph-filled space within the inner ear and the air-filled middle ear or mastoid. This can lead to the leakage of perilymph fluid, causing symptoms such as sudden onset vertigo, hearing loss, and sometimes tinnitus, especially after events that change ear pressure like diving, flying, or heavy lifting. The presence of vertigo and hearing loss after a pressure event (like scuba diving) with an intact tympanic membrane strongly suggests a perilymph fistula.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Meniere's disease typically presents with episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. These episodes can last from 20 minutes to several hours, not typically associated with diving or immediate onset after a pressure change.

 

Option B. Acoustic neuroma is a benign tumor of the cranial nerve VIII (vestibulocochlear nerve) that usually presents with progressive unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and sometimes balance disturbances. Its onset is gradual, not sudden after an event like diving.

 

Option D. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is characterized by brief episodes of vertigo related to head position changes. It is caused by dislodged otoliths moving into one of the semicircular canals, leading to inappropriate stimulation of the vestibular system. There's typically no hearing loss associated with BPPV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perilymph fistula is a cause of sudden onset vertigo and hearing loss following a pressure-altering event, distinguished by the absence of tympanic membrane inflammation or effusion, and negative findings for other causes of vertigo and hearing loss.

choices.text: Absence of nystagmus with both warm and cold water irrigation
Direction-changing nystagmus with warm water irrigation in the left ear and cold water irrigation in the right ear
Nystagmus beating toward the irrigated ear with warm water and away from the irrigated ear with cold water
Stronger nystagmus with cold water irrigation than with warm water irrigation in both ears

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of vertigo, particularly when she turns her head quickly. To assess her vestibular function, the physician decides to perform a Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test. Which of the following outcomes of this test is considered normal?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nystagmus beating toward the irrigated ear with warm water and away from the irrigated ear with cold water

 

Option C.

 

This is the correct answer and represents the normal response in the Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test. Warm water irrigation causes endolymph in the semicircular canals to rise, simulating head movement towards the irrigated side, leading to nystagmus beating toward the irrigated ear. Conversely, cold water irrigation causes the endolymph to fall, simulating head movement away from the irrigated side, leading to nystagmus beating away from the irrigated ear.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Absence of nystagmus with both warm and cold water irrigation: This outcome is abnormal. The normal response to caloric testing involves the induction of nystagmus, which is a rapid, involuntary movement of the eyes. The absence of nystagmus may indicate a vestibular dysfunction.

 

Option B. Direction-changing nystagmus with warm water irrigation in the left ear and cold water irrigation in the right ear: While nystagmus direction can change based on the ear being irrigated and the temperature of the water, this option does not accurately describe the expected directional pattern for a normal response.

 

Option D. Stronger nystagmus with cold water irrigation than with warm water irrigation in both ears: The strength of nystagmus is not the primary indicator of a normal response in the caloric test. The direction of the nystagmus in relation to the ear being irrigated and the temperature of the water is more relevant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test evaluates vestibular function by inducing nystagmus through the irrigation of the external auditory canal with warm and cold water. The normal response is nystagmus that beats toward the irrigated ear with warm water and away with cold water.

choices.text: It is the longest segment of the facial nerve and lies within the internal acoustic meatus
It extends from the geniculate ganglion to the stylomastoid foramen
It is the shortest and narrowest segment, making it vulnerable to compression-related paralysis
It lies below the oval window and lateral semicircular canal

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is the shortest and narrowest segment, making it vulnerable to compression-related paralysis

 

  • The labyrinthine segment is just 4 mm long and has the narrowest bony canal (0.61–0.68 mm), making it the most vulnerable segment to inflammation or edema, which can cause facial nerve paralysis.

 

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It is the longest segment of the facial nerve and lies within the internal acoustic meatus: Incorrect. The meatal segment lies within the internal acoustic meatus and measures 8–10 mm, but the labyrinthine segment is shorter (about 4 mm).

 

Option B. It extends from the geniculate ganglion to the stylomastoid foramen
Incorrect. This describes the combined tympanic and mastoid segments, not the labyrinthine segment.

 

Option D. It lies below the oval window and lateral semicircular canal
Incorrect. This describes the tympanic (horizontal) segment, not the labyrinthine segment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve is the shortest and narrowest portion, making it highly susceptible to compression-induced facial paralysis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 90

choices.text: CROS aids use a bone conduction oscillator placed on the mastoid of the deaf ear
CROS aids are primarily used in bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss
CROS aids deliver sound from the better ear to the poorer ear for improved clarity
CROS aids transmit sound from the deaf ear to the better ear to improve sound awareness on the deaf side

questions.text: Which of the following statements about CROS (Contralateral Routing of Signals) hearing aids is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CROS aids transmit sound from the deaf ear to the better ear to improve sound awareness on the deaf side

 

  • CROS hearing aids are used in single-sided deafness, where they route sound from the non-hearing side to the hearing side, improving awareness and localization. However, bone-anchored hearing aids are now preferred alternatives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CROS aids use a bone conduction oscillator placed on the mastoid of the deaf ear: Incorrect. This describes bone conduction hearing aids or bone-anchored hearing aids (BAHA), not CROS. CROS aids use a microphone on the deaf side and receiver on the normal side.

 

Option B. CROS aids are primarily used in bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss: Incorrect. CROS aids are specifically designed for unilateral profound hearing loss, not bilateral.

 

Option C. CROS aids deliver sound from the better ear to the poorer ear for improved clarity: Incorrect. It is the reverse — CROS aids pick up sound from the deaf ear side and send it to the better ear to help with sound localization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CROS hearing aids route sound from the deaf ear to the better ear, helping with sound localization in cases of single-sided deafness.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 122

choices.text: Cricotracheal membrane connecting cricoid cartilage to trachea
Cricovocal membrane forming the vocal ligament and conus elasticus
Thyrohyoid membrane pierced by internal laryngeal nerve
Aryepiglottic fold containing the cuneiform cartilage

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with sudden-onset respiratory distress after suspected inhalation of a small toy part. Imaging reveals the foreign body lodged in the subglottic region. Which of the following intrinsic laryngeal structures is most likely involved in the impaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cricovocal membrane forming the vocal ligament and conus elasticus

 

 

  • The cricovocal membrane is a triangular fibroelastic structure considered an intrinsic membrane of the larynx.
  • Its upper free border stretches from the middle of the thyroid angle to the vocal process of the arytenoid cartilage, forming the vocal ligament.
  • Its lower border is attached to the arch of the cricoid cartilage.
  • Together with its counterpart on the opposite side, it forms the conus elasticus, a cone-shaped membrane below the vocal cords.
  • Subglottic foreign bodies often get impacted in the conus elasticus, making it clinically significant in airway emergencies.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Cricotracheal membrane connecting cricoid cartilage to trachea: Incorrect. Cricotracheal membrane is extrinsic and connects cricoid cartilage to the trachea; it’s not part of conus elasticus.

Option C. Thyrohyoid membrane pierced by internal laryngeal nerve: Incorrect. Thyrohyoid membrane is extrinsic and pierced by the internal laryngeal nerve; unrelated to subglottic obstruction.

Option D. Aryepiglottic fold containing the cuneiform cartilage: Incorrect. Aryepiglottic fold is supraglottic, and not involved in subglottic foreign body impaction.

 

Educational Objective:


The cricovocal membrane forms the vocal ligament and, with its opposite side, forms the conus elasticus, where subglottic foreign bodies may get impacted.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 283

choices.text: Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy
Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
External branch of superior laryngeal nerve injury

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with persistent choking while eating, frequent bouts of coughing during swallowing, and a weak, husky voice. He has a recent history of cervical lymphadenopathy and was treated for diphtheria two months ago. Laryngoscopic examination reveals bilateral flaccid vocal cords and loss of protective airway reflexes. Which of the following best explains the clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy

 

Paralysis of both cricothyroid muscles leads to weak and husky voice. Bilateral sensory loss above vocal cords results in absence of protective reflexes, leading to aspiration of food and secretions, cough, and choking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy: Incorrect. This results in bilateral abductor paralysis with stridor and airway obstruction but voice is usually good. Aspiration is not a predominant symptom unless glottic incompetence is severe.

 

Option C. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy: Incorrect. Usually asymptomatic or mild hoarseness without aspiration. Does not cause bilateral symptoms like choking on both sides.

 

Option D. External branch of superior laryngeal nerve injury: Incorrect. Involves only the motor function to cricothyroid muscle on one side, leading to inability to raise pitch. No sensory deficit or aspiration.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy causes weak voice and aspiration due to loss of cricothyroid function and bilateral sensory loss above the glottis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 300

choices.text: Bilateral vocal cord decortication in the same sitting
Unilateral decortication followed by contralateral decortication after a few weeks
Botulinum toxin injection to the thyroarytenoid muscle

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a long history of voice abuse and smoking presents with gradually progressive hoarseness. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals bilateral fusiform, translucent swellings over the membranous vocal cords consistent with Reinke’s edema. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Unilateral decortication followed by contralateral decortication after a few weeks

 

This is the standard surgical treatment for Reinke’s edema. The procedure involves removing a strip of edematous mucosa (decortication). It is done one side at a time to preserve airway and voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral vocal cord decortication in the same sitting: Can lead to airway compromise and poor voice outcome. Not recommended.

 

Option C. Botulinum toxin injection to the thyroarytenoid muscle : Used in spasmodic dysphonia, not Reinke’s edema.

 

Option D. Cordectomy with laser:  Too aggressive for benign lesions like Reinke’s edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinke’s edema is treated surgically by staged unilateral decortication of the vocal cords to remove edematous mucosa while preserving voice and airway.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 293

choices.text: It is part of the ethmoid bone and lies within the middle meatus
Its mucosa contains vascular channels running anterior to posterior
It attaches anteriorly to the maxilla and posteriorly to the palatine bone
It plays no role in humidifying inspired air

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the inferior turbinate is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It attaches anteriorly to the maxilla and posteriorly to the palatine bone

 

The inferior turbinate is a separate bone that is attached anteriorly to the maxilla and posteriorly to the palatine bone. It also connects to the lacrimal bone and uncinate process of ethmoid in between.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is part of the ethmoid bone and lies within the middle meatus: Incorrect. The inferior turbinate is a separate bone, unlike the superior and middle turbinates, which are part of the ethmoid bone. Also, it lies in the inferior meatus, not middle.

 

Option B. Its mucosa contains vascular channels running anterior to posterior: Incorrect. The vascular channels in the mucosa run from posterior to anterior, not anterior to posterior. This orientation helps maintain long contact with inspired air for effective humidification.

 

Option D. It plays no role in humidifying inspired air: Incorrect. The inferior turbinate plays a significant role in humidifying inspired air due to its vascular mucosa, which helps condition the air before it reaches the lungs.

 

Educational Objective:


The inferior turbinate is a separate bone attached to the maxilla and palatine bone, with posterior-to-anterior vascular channels in its mucosa aiding in humidification of inspired air.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 135

choices.text: Immediate Incision and Drainage in the Emergency Department

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with Nasal Trauma sustained during a Soccer Game. On examination, he has a Tender Fluctuant Swelling of the Nasal Septum. There is no evidence of nasal bone fracture or other facial injuries. The most likely diagnosis is a Septal Hematoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate Incision and Drainage in the Emergency Department 

 

Option B.

 

The correct answer is B. A septal hematoma should be drained as soon as possible to prevent complications like cartilage necrosis and septal perforation. This is usually done through a small incision under local anesthesia in the emergency department.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While antibiotics are important to prevent infection, they are not sufficient as the sole treatment for a septal hematoma. A septal hematoma requires active intervention to prevent complications.

 

Option C. Nasal decongestants and analgesics may provide symptomatic relief for nasal congestion and pain but do not address the underlying issue of a septal hematoma.

 

Option D. While cold compresses can help reduce swelling, observation alone is not an appropriate management strategy for a septal hematoma due to the risk of complications.

 

Septal hematoma –

 

Collection of blood between cartilage and it’s perichondrium.

 

 

 

Causes – trauma, surgery, bleeding disorders.

 

Clinical features – Bilateral obstruction, frontal headache, sense of pressure over nasal bridge.

 

Examination – smooth rounded swelling of septum in both cavities.

 

On palpation → soft & fluctuant.

 

Treatment – Incision & drainage immediately, then packing + antibiotics.

 

Complications –

 

(1) Fibrous Change → permanently thickened septum.

(2) Secondary Infection → abscess with cartilage necrosis → Dorsum Depressed (Saddling).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate management of a septal hematoma involves immediate incision and drainage in the emergency department to prevent complications like cartilage necrosis and septal perforation. This knowledge is essential for medical residents, particularly in emergency medicine and otolaryngology, for the effective management of nasal trauma-related complications.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, Pg 176-180

choices.text: Nasal obstruction reduces filtration of large particles, leading to direct alveolar damage.
Impaired nasal humidification decreases ciliary function, affecting mucociliary clearance and gas exchange.
Loss of nasal vibrissae function causes excessive warming of inspired air, resulting in hyperthermia.
Nasal mucosa vascular sinusoids constrict excessively, reducing oxygen absorption in the nasal cavity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with chronic nasal obstruction complains of frequent episodes of dry cough and worsened breathing at night. Pulmonary function tests show mild hypoxemia and elevated arterial pCO₂. Which of the following best explains how nasal obstruction can contribute to these respiratory abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Impaired nasal humidification decreases ciliary function, affecting mucociliary clearance and gas exchange.

 

The nasal mucosa humidifies inspired air to maintain relative humidity around 75% or more. Dry air due to nasal obstruction reduces humidification, leading to impaired ciliary function (which stops within 8–10 minutes at 50% humidity). This impairs mucociliary clearance, predisposing to respiratory infections and reduces effective gas exchange in the lungs, leading to hypoxemia and elevated pCO₂.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasal obstruction reduces filtration of large particles, leading to direct alveolar damage: Incorrect. While the nose filters larger particles using vibrissae and mucus, direct alveolar damage from reduced filtration is less common; smaller particles <0.5 μm bypass the nose normally.

 

Option C. Loss of nasal vibrissae function causes excessive warming of inspired air, resulting in hyperthermia: Incorrect. Nasal mucosa vascular sinusoids act as a “radiator” warming or cooling inspired air to body temperature, but loss of vibrissae does not cause excessive warming or hyperthermia.

 

Option D. Nasal mucosa vascular sinusoids constrict excessively, reducing oxygen absorption in the nasal cavity: Incorrect. Nasal mucosa vascular sinusoids regulate blood flow to control temperature, but oxygen absorption does not occur in the nasal cavity; oxygen exchange happens in the lungs.

 

Additional points:

 

  • Nasal vibrissae filter large particles (>3 μm), while mucus traps finer particles (0.5–3 μm).
  • Inspired air temperature is rapidly adjusted from cold or hot ambient temperature to near 37°C within one-fourth second.
  • Approximately 1000 mL of water evaporates daily from nasal mucosa, crucial for humidification and ciliary function.
  • Nasal obstruction can impair lung function, causing apneic spells and altered blood gases during sleep.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasal obstruction impairs humidification of inspired air, leading to decreased ciliary function and compromised gas exchange, resulting in hypoxemia and elevated pCO₂.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 140

choices.text: Passavant’s ridge is formed by palatoglossus and palatopharyngeus muscles at the level of the oropharynx
Thornwaldt cyst is a remnant of the second pharyngeal pouch and arises from the lateral wall of the nasopharynx
Fossa of Rosenmüller lies posterior to torus tubarius and is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma
Sphenopalatine foramen opens into the nasopharynx and is formed by the maxilla and vomer bones

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding pharyngeal and adjacent anatomical structures is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fossa of Rosenmüller lies posterior to torus tubarius and is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma

 

The fossa of Rosenmüller is a recess in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx, lying posterior to the torus tubarius (the bulge caused by the cartilaginous end of the Eustachian tube), and is the most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

 

Key anatomical facts from the content:

 

  • Adenoids: Located at the junction of roof and posterior wall of nasopharynx
  • Thornwaldt cyst/nasopharyngeal bursa: Remnant of notochord, arises from the same area as adenoids
  • Torus tubarius: Bulge due to Eustachian tube opening
  • Fossa of Rosenmüller: Posterior to torus tubarius, common site of nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Sphenopalatine foramen: Lies 1 cm posterior to end of middle turbinate, formed by palatine bone (perpendicular plate) and pterygoid part of sphenoid; it opens into pterygopalatine fossa and is the most common site for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA)
  • Pterygopalatine fossa: Between maxillary sinus and pterygoid part of sphenoid; connects laterally to infratemporal fossa via pterygomaxillary fissure
  • Passavant’s ridge: Muscular ridge formed by palatopharyngeus and superior constrictor, blocks nasopharynx during swallowing
  • Palatine tonsils: Located in oropharynx between palatoglossus (anterior pillar) and palatopharyngeus (posterior pillar)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Passavant’s ridge is formed by palatoglossus and palatopharyngeus muscles at the level of the oropharynx: Incorrect – Passavant’s ridge is formed by palatopharyngeus and superior constrictor, not by palatoglossus

 

Option B. Thornwaldt cyst is a remnant of the second pharyngeal pouch and arises from the lateral wall of the nasopharynx: Incorrect – Thornwaldt cyst is a remnant of the notochord, not the second pharyngeal pouch, and arises from the posterior wall, not lateral wall

 

Option D. Sphenopalatine foramen opens into the nasopharynx and is formed by the maxilla and vomer bones: Incorrect – Sphenopalatine foramen is formed by the perpendicular plate of palatine bone and pterygoid process of sphenoid, not maxilla and vomer, and it opens into the nasal cavity, not nasopharynx

 

Educational Objective:
 

The fossa of Rosenmüller, located posterior to the torus tubarius, is the most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 254

choices.text: IV antibiotics and emergency incision and drainage
Incision and drainage followed by full antitubercular therapy

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with mild dysphagia, posterior throat discomfort, and a gradually enlarging midline swelling on the posterior pharyngeal wall. He also has multiple cervical lymph nodes and a history of weight loss and low-grade fever. Cervical spine X-ray reveals destruction of C3 and C4 vertebral bodies. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incision and drainage followed by full antitubercular therapy

 

This is the standard treatment for tubercular prevertebral abscesses.

 

This is a classic presentation of a chronic retropharyngeal abscess (specifically a prevertebral abscess) due to tuberculosis:

 

  • Most commonly caused by cervical spine tuberculosis (Pott’s disease)
  • Abscess lies behind the prevertebral fascia, usually midline
  • Often has minimal symptoms like mild dysphagia and throat discomfort
  • Cervical spine X-ray is diagnostic (shows vertebral destruction)
  • May be associated with tuberculous cervical lymphadenopathy

 

Management:

 

  • Incision and drainage via:
    • Anterior border of sternocleidomastoid (for low abscesses)
    • Posterior border (for high abscesses)
  • Full course of ATT (antitubercular therapy) is essential to prevent recurrence and control infection

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV antibiotics and emergency drainage: Suitable for acute pyogenic abscess, not tubercular. Also, ATT is essential.

 

Option C. Oral steroids and observation: Steroids may worsen TB if given alone; definitive drainage and ATT are necessary.

 

Option D. Immediate tracheostomy: Airway obstruction is not typical in chronic prevertebral TB abscess. Tracheostomy is reserved for acute airway compromise, e.g., in Ludwig’s angina or acute retropharyngeal abscess.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Chronic retropharyngeal abscess due to cervical spine tuberculosis is treated with incision and drainage followed by a full course of antitubercular therapy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 267

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding mucocele is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a bluish, soft cystic lesion most commonly found on the lower lip and arises from minor salivary glands

 

This option accurately summarizes the most common site (lower lip), lesion characteristics (soft, bluish), and origin (minor salivary glands).

 

A mucocele is a retention cyst that forms due to blockage or rupture of the duct of a minor salivary gland, resulting in mucus extravasation and a cyst-like swelling. Key clinical features include:

 

  • Most common site: Lower lip
  • Appearance: Soft, bluish, cystic swelling
  • Etiology: Often caused by trauma (e.g., lip biting)
  • Treatment: Surgical excision is the treatment of choice to prevent recurrence

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. It is a neoplastic lesion typically found on the tongue and requires chemotherapy: Incorrect. Mucoceles are not neoplastic and do not occur on the tongue; chemotherapy is not indicated.

 

Option C. It is a retention cyst of major salivary glands and is commonly found over the parotid duct: Incorrect. Mucoceles arise from minor, not major salivary glands; the parotid duct is unrelated to mucocele formation.

 

Option D. Observation is sufficient in most cases as mucoceles tend to resolve spontaneously without intervention: Incorrect. While some small mucoceles may temporarily regress, most require surgical excision to prevent recurrence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucocele is a bluish, soft cystic lesion of minor salivary glands, most commonly on the lower lip, and requires surgical excision.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with recurrent frontal headaches, especially in the mornings, and tenderness above the supraorbital margin. CT scan shows mucosal thickening in the frontal sinus and blockage of the frontal recess. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the anatomy and drainage of the frontal sinus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Frontal recess is bounded anteriorly by agger nasi cells and posteriorly by bulla ethmoidalis

 

Frontal sinus drains into the superior meatus through the nasofrontal duct: Incorrect. It drains into the anterior part of the middle meatus via the frontal recess. The term “nasofrontal duct” is outdated and incorrect as no true duct exists.

 

 

This patient presents with:

 

  • Morning frontal headaches
  • Tenderness above the supraorbital margin
  • CT evidence of frontal sinusitis with frontal recess obstruction

 

The frontal sinus lies above and deep to the supraorbital margin, situated between the inner and outer tables of the frontal bone. Its drainage pathway is through the frontal ostium into the frontal recess, which is anatomically bounded by:

 

  • Middle turbinate (medially)
  • Lamina papyracea (laterally)
  • Agger nasi cells (anteriorly)
  • Bulla ethmoidalis (posteriorly)

 

Obstruction of this narrow and often tortuous drainage pathway by anterior ethmoidal cells can cause frontal sinusitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontal sinus lies below the supraorbital margin between the two plates of ethmoid bone: Incorrect. It lies above and deep to the supraorbital margin, within the frontal bone, not ethmoid bone.

 

Option C. Frontal recess is bounded anteriorly by agger nasi cells and posteriorly by bulla ethmoidalis: Correct. This relationship defines the anatomy of the frontal recess, and is crucial in understanding obstruction mechanisms in frontal sinusitis.

 

Option D. The intersinus septum of frontal sinuses is thick and centrally placed in all individuals: Incorrect. The septum is often thin, oblique, or even absent, and the two sinuses are often asymmetrical.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal sinus drains into the middle meatus via the frontal recess, which is bounded anteriorly by agger nasi cells and posteriorly by bulla ethmoidalis.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 187

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presented with mild ocular redness for the past 4 months. On examination, he had large keratic precipitates with minimal flare. The likely etiology for this condition includes all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reiter syndrome

 

Option C.

 

  • The given case scenario is suggestive of granulomatous uveitis.

  • It is characterized by the presence of large, greasy ‘mutton fat’ keratic precipitates which are deposits of white blood cells (Mainly lymphocytes) derived from the aqueous on the corneal endothelium.

  • It has a chronic presentation with quiescent inflammatory reaction.

  • Differentials of granulomatous uveitis include:

 

  1. TB

  2. Syphilis

  3. Sarcoidosis

  4. VKH

  5. Sympathetic ophthalmitis

  6. Leptospirosis

  7. HSV

 

Explanation:

 

Reiter's syndrome, also known as reactive arthritis, is a type of inflammatory arthritis that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body, often the intestines, genitals, or urinary tract. It is classified as a form of spondyloarthritis, which is a group of joint diseases that specifically affect the spine and the areas where the tendons and ligaments attach to bones.

 

The key features of Reiter's syndrome include:

 

  1. Arthritis: Swelling, pain, and stiffness of the joints, especially the knees, ankles, and feet. It can also affect the fingers, wrists, elbows, and spine.

  2. Urethritis: Inflammation of the urethra, which can cause pain during urination and an increased urge to urinate.

  3. Conjunctivitis: Inflammation of the lining of the eye, leading to redness, irritation, and discomfort.

  4. Enthesitis: Inflammation at the sites where tendons or ligaments insert into the bone, particularly at the heels, toes, or spine.

  5. Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions: Some people may develop skin rashes, sores in the mouth, or keratoderma blennorrhagica (small, painless, hard nodules on the palms and soles).

 

The exact cause of Reiter's syndrome is not known, but it is believed to be triggered by certain bacterial infections. Commonly implicated bacteria include Chlamydia trachomatis, which is sexually transmitted, and certain gastrointestinal bacteria like Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, and Campylobacter.

 

The treatment of Reiter's syndrome focuses on relieving symptoms and includes the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), corticosteroids, and disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs). Antibiotics may be used if a bacterial infection is identified as the trigger. Additionally, physical therapy can help maintain joint function and range of motion.

 

Most people with Reiter's syndrome recover fully from the initial episode within 12 months, but some may experience chronic arthritis or recurrent episodes of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

By analyzing the case of a 37-year-old male with chronic ocular redness and identifying the presence of large keratic precipitates with minimal flare,the diagnosis is  granulomatous anterior uveitis. Cause of this clinical picture are Herpes simplex, Tuberculosis, and Sarcoidosis. Reiter's syndrome, also known as reactive arthritis, is the classic triad of conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis occurring after an infection, particularly those in the urogenital or gastrointestinal tract.

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of the eye 22nd edition

questions.text: A cataract surgeon noticed zonular dehiscence in a patient preoperatively of less than 2 clock hours. What precaution can be taken during surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Capsular Tension Rings (CTR) Insertion

 

Option D.

 

  • The presence of zonular weakness increases the risk of intra- and postoperative complications from cataract surgery, including posterior capsular rupture, vitreous loss, and lens dislocation and decentration.
  • Capsular support devices facilitate safe and successful cataract surgery by improving capsular bag stability and centration.
  • These devices consist of capsular tension rings (A), modified capsular tension rings (B), capsular tension segments (C), and capsular retention hooks (D). 


 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Iris hooks are used to mechanically dilate the pupil in cases where pharmacological dilation is insufficient. While they provide better visualization during surgery, they do not address zonular dehiscence or the stability of the lens capsule.

 

Option B. Multifocal IOLs provide a range of vision post-cataract surgery but have no role in managing zonular dehiscence. The choice of IOL doesn't directly impact the surgical approach to zonular weakness.

 

Option C. LASIK (Laser-Assisted in Situ Keratomileusis) is a refractive surgery procedure for correcting vision issues like myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism. It is unrelated to the management of zonular dehiscence in cataract surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the scenario of zonular dehiscence of less than 2 clock hours, the precaution that can be taken during cataract surgery is - Capsular Tension Rings (CTR) insertion. This approach helps to manage the weakened zonular support effectively, ensuring a safer surgical procedure and better outcomes.

 

Ref: https://eyewiki.aao.org/Capsular_Support_Devices

questions.text: In FLACS (Femto Laser Assisted Cataract Surgery), what is the Femto Laser used for?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above

 

Option D.

 

  • Femtosecond laser assisted cataract surgery (FLACS) is a recent development in the history of cataract surgery.
  • The femtosecond laser can be used to create cleavage planes via photo disruption in transparent/translucent tissues.
  • The laser can be used to assist the surgeon by creating tissue planes for:
    1. Wounds
    2. Arcuate Keratotomies
    3. Anterior Capsulotomies
    4. Nuclear Fragmentation

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterior Capsulotomy: The femtosecond laser is used to create a precise, circular incision in the anterior capsule of the lens, which is a critical step for accessing and removing the cataract. This laser-assisted capsulotomy is known for its precision and reproducibility compared to the manual technique.

 

Option B. Arcuate Keratotomies: The femtosecond laser can also be used to perform arcuate keratotomies, which are precise incisions in the cornea to correct pre-existing astigmatism. This enhances the refractive outcomes of cataract surgery.

 

Option C. Nuclear Fragmentation: The femtosecond laser can pre-fragment the cataractous lens (nucleus) which can reduce the amount of ultrasound energy (phacoemulsification) needed to subsequently break up and remove the lens material, potentially leading to less trauma to the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The femtosecond laser in FLACS is a versatile tool that enhances the precision, safety, and refractive outcomes of cataract surgery by assisting in multiple key steps of the procedure.

 

Ref: https://eyewiki.aao.org/Femtosecond_Cataract_Surgery

questions.text: In case of posterior capsular rupture, where are the GLUED IOLs placed?

Ans. C) Behind the Iris

 

Option C.

  • The glued IOL technique consists of making two partial-thickness scleral flaps exactly 180 degrees apart.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. In the Anterior Chamber IOLs are placed in front of the iris. This option is generally considered when there is inadequate support in the posterior chamber, but it's less favored due to potential complications like corneal endothelial damage and secondary glaucoma.

 

 

 

Option B. Attached to Iris-fixated IOLs are another option where the lens is attached to the iris. This can be done in cases where there is insufficient capsular support, but it requires sufficient structural integrity of the iris and careful consideration of potential complications, such as iris chafing.

 

 

Option D. None of the Above: This option is incorrect given that one of the above choices accurately describes the placement of glued IOLs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that in cases of posterior capsular rupture, glued intraocular lenses (IOLs) are typically placed in the sulcus, behind the iris, using a technique that secures the IOL to the sclera with fibrin glue for stable fixation.

 

Ref:  https://www.aao.org/education/current-insight/glued-iol-technique

questions.text: Which among the following is a method of short-term storage after eye ball retrieval?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Moist chamber storage

 

Option B.

 

Whole globe is sealed in a container and stored at 4 degree C.

 

Short-term (upto 48 hours) = Moist chamber storage

 

 

Intermediate (2 weeks) = MK medium, optisol

 

Long-term (35 days) = Organ culture method, cryopreservation

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MK Medium (McCarey-Kaufman Medium): This is a medium used for the storage of corneal tissues. However, MK medium is typically used for short-term preservation of up to 4 days. It's often used in scenarios where corneal transplantation is planned shortly after retrieval.

 

 

Option C. Cryopreservation: This method involves freezing the tissue for long-term storage. Cryopreservation is not commonly used for corneal storage due to the risk of damaging the corneal endothelial cells during the freeze-thaw process.

 

Option D. Organ Culture Method: This is a method used for longer-term storage of corneal tissues, allowing storage for up to 4 weeks. It involves keeping the cornea in a special nutrient medium at a controlled temperature, which is higher than that used in MK medium or moist chamber storage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Moist chamber storage is a method used for the short-term storage of corneal tissue after eyeball retrieval, suitable for maintaining the viability of the cornea for up to 24-48 hours.

 

Ref: pg 137/ systemic & community ophthal/ AK KHURANA comprehensive ophthalmology / 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the guidelines laid down by the government of India for organising eye camps?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) At least 5 operating surgeons should be present

 

Option B.

 

  • At least 1, preferably 2 operating surgeons should perform cataract surgeries.

  • Presently both SICS & PHACOEMULSIFICATION techniques are performed.

  • Both eyes should never be operated at one go.

  • Cases with associated risk factors should be referred to base hospitals.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Presently SICS & Phacoemulsification Techniques are Recommended: Small Incision Cataract Surgery (SICS) and Phacoemulsification are modern and efficient techniques for cataract surgery. These methods are indeed recommended for their safety, effectiveness, and relatively quick recovery times.

 

Option C. Both the Eyes Should Never be Operated at One Go: This is a standard guideline in eye care, especially in camp settings. Operating on both eyes simultaneously increases the risk of complications, including infection. Therefore, it is recommended to operate on one eye at a time.

 

Option D. Cases with Surgical Risks Such as Diabetes, Hypertensives & Cardiac Problems Should Not be Operated in Camps: This statement is generally true. Patients with systemic conditions like diabetes, hypertension, or cardiac problems are at a higher risk of complications during and after surgery. Such cases typically require more comprehensive pre-operative and post-operative care than what might be available at an eye camp.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that the requirement of having at least 5 operating surgeons at eye camps is not a standardized guideline by the Government of India, unlike the recommendations for SICS & Phacoemulsification techniques, the practice of not operating on both eyes simultaneously, and the avoidance of operating on high-risk patients in camp settings.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to a pediatric ophthalmology clinic with enlarged and cloudy corneas, excessive tearing, and light sensitivity. Examination reveals increased intraocular pressure, corneal edema, and increased cup:disc ratio of the optic nerve head. The diagnosis of developmental glaucoma (congenital glaucoma) is made. All of the following drugs can be given to lower the IOP except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brimonidine

 

Option C.

 

  • Brimonidine is an alpha-agonist that reduces the production of aqueous humour and increases aqueous outflow via uveoscleral pathway.
  • It can cross blood-brain barrier and cause drowsiness and respiratory depression in infants and children and is therefore contraindicated in them.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dorzolamide is a topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that decreases aqueous humour production. It is generally considered safe and can be used in infants to lower IOP.

 

Option B. Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue used to increase the outflow of aqueous humour, thereby lowering IOP. It is generally safe for use in infants, although monitoring for potential side effects like iris hyperpigmentation is important.

 

Option D. Betaxolol is a beta-blocker used in glaucoma to reduce aqueous humour production. It is generally safe for use in infants, although, like all systemic beta-blockers, it requires monitoring for potential respiratory and cardiovascular effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brimonidine, an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that reduces aqueous humour production and increases uveoscleral outflow, is not recommended for use in infants and young children due to the risk of severe side effects, including respiratory problems, lethargy, and decreased heart rate. It is contraindicated in children under the age of 2 years.

questions.text: A cataract surgery with a premium multifocal intraocular lens implantation is being planned. To assess the suitability of the patient to the MFIOL, the surgeon is evaluating the angle alpha of the patient. Angle alpha is between:

Ans. A) Optical Axis and Visual Axis

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presented with complaints of decrease in vision in both eyes. He also give history of itching and irritation in both eyes, on and off. On examination, the conjunctiva shows cobblestone papillae and discrete white dots along the limbus. The diagnosis is?

questions.text: A patient undergoing perimetry has the following visual field defect. What is the pupillary abnormality expected in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wernicke’s pupil

 

Option D.

 

  • The picture shows right homonymous hemianopia.

  • Site of lesion – left optic tract.

  • This is associated with Wernicke’s pupil.

 

 

 

Wernicke Pupil

 

When the optic chiasm is bisected sagittally, the nasal halves of each retina become insensitive to light so that there is not only a bitemporal hemianopia but also a bitemporal pupillary hemiakinesia; that is, light falling on the nasal retina of either eye will fail to produce a pupillary constriction. Thus, if a very bright but small beam of light such as that produced by a slit lamp is shined on the nonseeing hemiretina of a patient with damage to the optic chiasm or optic tract and then is shined on the seeing hemiretina, it is possible to see that the pupil reacts better when the light shines on the seeing hemiretina than when it shines on the nonseeing retina.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Argyll Robertson Pupil: This is a condition where pupils are small and irregular but do not constrict when exposed to bright light (light-near dissociation). They do, however, constrict with accommodation. It is classically associated with neurosyphilis, particularly tabes dorsalis, and does not have a direct correlation with homonymous hemianopia.

 

Option B. Adie’s Pupil: Also known as tonic pupil, it is usually unilateral and is larger than the other pupil. It reacts poorly to light but may have a better near response. This condition is caused by damage to the postganglionic fibers of the parasympathetic innervation of the eye and is not related to visual field defects.

 

Option C. Marcus Gunn Pupil: Also known as a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), it is a sign of asymmetrical optic nerve dysfunction. It is detected using the swinging flashlight test. However, in homonymous hemianopia, the optic nerve function is typically preserved until the optic chiasm, so a Marcus Gunn pupil is not expected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case of right homonymous hemianopia, the lesion lies at the level of left optic tract, and the pupillary abnormality seen in these cases will be Wernicke’s pupil.

 

REF: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION pg.no: 312

questions.text: In Worth four dot test, the patient’s perception is shown in the image below.  What would be the interpretation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Orthophoria

 

Option C.

 

  • The test being done is Worth four-dot test – type of dissociation test.

  • Uses red-green goggles (red before right eye and green before left eye)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Right Suppression: A person with suppression of the right eye will see only two green dots because the right eye (covered by the red lens) suppresses the red dot, and the white dot appears green through the green lens of the left eye.

 

Option B. Left Suppression: A person with suppression of the left eye will see three dots - two green and one red. The left eye (covered by the green lens) suppresses the green dots, and the white dot appears red through the red lens of the right eye.

 

Option D. Diplopia: If the person has double vision (diplopia), they will see five dots - three green (two from the right eye and one white dot seen as green by the left eye) and two red (one from the left eye and one white dot seen as red by the right eye).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Worth Four Dot Test results vary based on the patient's visual condition: right suppression shows two green dots, left suppression shows two green and one red dot, orthophoria shows two green, one red, and one combined dot, and diplopia shows three green and two red dots.

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5TH EDITION PAGE 348

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of distressing thoughts that are recurrent and intrusive. He states these thoughts often go against his personal values and beliefs, causing him significant distress. He recognizes these thoughts as his own but feels they are not in line with his true self. Which of the following terms best describes the nature of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ego-dystonic

 

Option A.

 

Ego-dystonic: Thoughts or behaviors that are unwanted and unacceptable. This is the correct answer, as the patient recognizes the thoughts as his own but feels they are not consistent with his identity.

 

The nature of the patient's symptoms, where he feels the thoughts are against his personal values and beliefs, is described as ego-dystonic.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Ego-syntonic: Thoughts or behaviors that are in harmony with the needs and goals of the self. These are consistent with a person's self-image, and the individual doesn't see them as problematic.

 

Option C: Ego-ideal: This is a psychoanalytic term representing an individual's idealized self, the embodiment of all the qualities one aspires to have.

 

Option D: Ego-neutral: This term is not standardly used in clinical psychology or psychiatry. Ego-neutral would imply that something is neither congruent nor in conflict with the self-image or ego.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obsessions, as seen in Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD), are typically ego-dystonic, meaning thoughts or behaviors that are unwanted and unacceptable. On the other hand, certain personality disorders might have traits that are ego-syntonic, where the behaviors or thoughts are not seen as problematic by the individual, even if they are maladaptive.

 

Ref: Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 5th edition, Page No 46.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to a psychiatrist with a history of excessive happiness, hyper-religiosity, and increased energy for the past 10 days. He reports needing only 4 hours of sleep each night and has been unusually talkative at work. Based on his symptoms, he was diagnosed with a hypomanic episode. Additionally, his medical history reveals three episodes of depression and one episode of mania in the past. What is the diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bipolar Type 1 Disorder

 

Option A.

 

Bipolar Type 1 Disorder is diagnosed when a patient experiences at least one manic episode, which may be preceded or followed by hypomanic or major depressive episodes. In this case, the patient has experienced one manic episode and three depressive episodes in the past, in addition to the current hypomanic episode. Therefore, the likely diagnosis is Bipolar Type 1 Disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bipolar Type 2 Disorder is characterized by the presence of at least one hypomanic episode and at least one major depressive episode, without any manic episodes. The patient's history of one manic episode excludes the diagnosis of Bipolar Type 2 Disorder.

 

Option C. Cyclothymia is a chronic mood disorder characterized by hypomanic and depressive symptoms that do not meet the criteria for a hypomanic episode or major depressive episode. The symptoms must be present for at least two years.. The presence of a manic episode and major depressive episodes in this patient's history rules out a diagnosis of cyclothymia.

 

Option D. Recurrent Depressive Disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of major depression without any history of mania or hypomania. The patient's history of a manic episode and hypomanic episode excludes the diagnosis of Recurrent Depressive Disorder. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A single manic/mixed episode is enough to make the diagnosis of Bipolar type I disorder. The patient in the case has a history of one manic episode, which is sufficient for a diagnosis of Bipolar Type I Disorder, regardless of the current hypomanic episode or the past depressive episodes

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 366-368.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is diagnosed with borderline personality disorder after multiple presentations to the psychiatric clinic, each time with intense interpersonal issues, impulsivity, and self-harm tendencies. As part of her comprehensive treatment plan, which therapeutic approach has been shown to be the most effective in managing individuals with this disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT).

 

Option B.

 

Borderline personality disorder (BPD) is a challenging condition to treat. However, Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT) has been specifically developed for, and has shown to be the most effective for, BPD patients, particularly those with a history of self-harm or suicidal behaviors. DBT is a form of cognitive-behavioral therapy that focuses on teaching coping skills to combat destructive urges, improve relationships, and increase emotional awareness.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT): While CBT can be useful for certain symptoms and can be a part of the treatment regime, DBT is the primary therapeutic approach specifically designed for BPD.

 

Option C. Group therapy: Group therapy can be beneficial in treating some aspects of BPD, but it isn't the primary therapeutic modality used for this condition.

 

Option D. Psychodynamic psychotherapy: While this approach can offer insights into unconscious thought patterns and behaviors, it's not the first-line therapy for BPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dialectical behavior therapy is a therapy that has been designed for the treatment of borderline personality disorder. Medications used in BPD include antipsychotics, antidepressants, and mood stabilizers like carbamazepine.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 573.

choices.text: Diagnosed based on severity and predominant personality traits
Based on the presence of psychotic symptoms
Diagnosed only in individuals above 30 years of age

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the psychiatric clinic with a history of unstable relationships, impulsive behavior, and intense episodes of anger. She reports a chronic feeling of emptiness and struggles with self-identity. Her psychiatrist considers a personality disorder diagnosis as per ICD-11 criteria. Which of the following best describes the classification of personality disorders in ICD-11?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diagnosed based on severity and predominant personality traits

 

Option B.

 

The International Classification of Diseases, 11th Revision (ICD-11) has adopted a new approach to classifying personality disorders. Unlike the previous version, ICD-11 does not categorize personality disorders into specific types (such as borderline, antisocial, etc.). Instead, it focuses on the severity of the dysfunction (mild, moderate, or severe) and predominant personality traits or patterns that can be described in terms of five broad domains: negative affectivity, detachment, dissociality, disinhibition, and anankastia. The new classification is intended to reduce overlap between diagnoses and to provide a more flexible framework that can capture the full range of personality pathology.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Categorized into 10 specific types: This describes the classification system used by the DSM-5, not ICD-11.

 

Option C. Based on the presence of psychotic symptoms: Psychotic symptoms are not used to classify personality disorders in ICD-11. Personality disorders are characterized by enduring patterns of behavior and inner experience that deviate markedly from the expectations of the individual's culture, are pervasive and inflexible, and lead to distress or impairment.

 

Option D. Diagnosed only in individuals above 30 years of age: Personality disorders can be diagnosed in adults of any age, not just those above 30, as long as the maladaptive patterns are stable over time and lead to distress or impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ICD-11, the older classification of personality disorders (e.g. schizoid, paranoid, narcissistic, etc) has been removed. According to ICD-11, personality disorders have been divided according to the severity of symptoms into:

 

  • Mild personality disorder

  • Moderate personality disorder

  • Severe personality disorder

 

According to ICD-11, depending on the specific symptoms present, a specifier of a prominent personality trait' can be added after the diagnosis, e.g. a person who does not follow rules doesn't care for the feelings of others, does not have any guilt feeling will get a diagnosis of moderate personality disorder (dissociality in personality disorder). This patient according to ICD-10 would have received a diagnosis of Dissocial Personality disorder.

 

Ref: International Classification of Diseases, 11th edition, Page No 174-177.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female patient presents to the clinic with significant weight loss over the past eight months. She reports an intense fear of gaining weight and a persistent dissatisfaction with her body image. Her BMI is 16.2 kg/m². She also admits to engaging in episodes of binge eating followed by purging behaviors, such as self-induced vomiting and excessive exercise. What is the most appropriate diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anorexia nervosa, binge-eating/purging type

 

Option B.

 

The patient presents with features of anorexia nervosa, such as a significantly low BMI (BMI < 18.5 kg/m2), fear of weight gain, and body image disturbance. Additionally, she reports episodes of binge eating followed by purging behaviors. This combination of symptoms is consistent with a diagnosis of anorexia nervosa, binge-eating/purging type (option B). 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anorexia nervosa, restrictive type is characterized by weight loss achieved primarily through dieting, fasting, or excessive exercise without regular episodes of binge eating and purging. 

 

Option C. Bulimia nervosa, purging type and Option D. Bulimia nervosa, non purging type involve recurrent episodes of binge eating and compensatory behaviors to prevent weight gain, but patients with bulimia nervosa typically have a normal body weight or are slightly overweight and Since the patient has a BMI of 16.2 kg/m², which is well below normal, this rules out bulimia nervosa..

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anorexia nervosa, binge-eating type is characterized by significant weight loss, a distorted body image, and episodes of binge eating followed by compensatory behaviors such as self-induced vomiting or misuse of laxatives. In anorexia nervosa, the patient has a significantly low weight (BMI < 18.5 kg/m²), while in bulimia nervosa, weight is typically normal or slightly elevated and the presence of binge-eating and purging behaviors determines the subtype (restrictive vs. binge-eating/purging), but does not change the primary diagnosis.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 471.

questions.text: You are consulted regarding a 14-year-old boy who has recently been displaying symptoms of depression. His school teacher reports that he appeared to become sad suddenly over a week, often seeming distant and preoccupied. His mother shares that he has moments where he claims to hear voices telling him he's worthless. On some days, he shifts rapidly between bouts of crying and periods of irritability. During the clinic visit, you observe that he frequently fidgets, can't sit still, and displays signs of restlessness. Given this presentation, which of the following features in this child's depressive episode is least indicative of a future risk of developing bipolar disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Psychomotor agitation

 

Option D.

 

Among the features listed in the child's presentation, psychomotor agitation is the least indicative of a future risk of developing bipolar disorder. Psychomotor agitation, which includes symptoms like restlessness and fidgeting, can be a feature of depression and is not specifically indicative of bipolar disorder.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rapid onset of depression: A sudden or rapid onset of depressive symptoms can be indicative of bipolar disorder, as mood episodes in bipolar disorder often have a more acute onset compared to unipolar depression.

 

Option B. Psychotic symptoms: The presence of psychotic symptoms, such as auditory hallucinations, during a depressive episode can suggest a higher likelihood of bipolar disorder. In pediatric cases, psychotic symptoms in depression warrant a careful assessment for bipolarity.

 

Option C. Mood lability: Rapid shifts in mood, such as quickly going from sadness to irritability, are suggestive of bipolarity and an increased risk of bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 385.

The duration criterion for diagnosis is 2 years
There is at least one episode of depression
There is at least one episode of hypomania

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the psychiatric clinic with a history of fluctuating mood patterns. She reports experiencing periods of elevated energy, increased creativity, and decreased need for sleep, but these episodes are not severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning. Additionally, she experiences periods of low mood, fatigue, and decreased interest in activities, but these episodes do not meet the full criteria for a major depressive episode. These mood fluctuations have been present for the past 3 years, with no symptom-free period lasting longer than 2 months. Based on her clinical presentation, which of the following statements is correct about her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The duration criterion for diagnosis is 2 years

 

Option B.

 

The clinical presentation of the 25-year-old female with fluctuating mood patterns that include periods of elevated energy, creativity, and decreased need for sleep (which are not severe enough to cause marked impairment) along with periods of low mood and fatigue, is indicative of Cyclothymic Disorder. Cyclothymic Disorder is characterized by chronic, fluctuating mood disturbances involving numerous periods of hypomanic symptoms and periods of depressive symptoms that do not meet the criteria for a major depressive episode. The key point in this diagnosis is the chronic nature of the condition, with the symptoms persisting for at least 2 years in adults (or 1 year in children and adolescents), without any symptom-free period extending longer than 2 months.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: There is at least one episode of mania: Mania is not present in Cyclothymic Disorder. If a manic episode occurs, the diagnosis would change to Bipolar I Disorder.

 

Option C: There is at least one episode of depression: The depressive symptoms in Cyclothymic Disorder do not meet the full criteria for a major depressive episode. 

 

Option D: There is at least one episode of hypomania: In Cyclothymic Disorder, while symptoms resembling hypomania are present, they may not always be sufficiently severe or prolonged to meet the full criteria for a hypomanic episode. Therefore, the presence of a hypomanic episode is not an absolute criterion for diagnosing cyclothymia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclothymia is a milder form of bipolar disorder, in which manic symptoms and depressive symptoms occur, but they are never severe enough to make a diagnosis of mania or depression. The symptoms should last for at least 2 years.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 369.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, previously diagnosed with bipolar disorder, is admitted due to an acute manic phase. She exhibits elation, rapid speech with frequent topic shifts, and claims she's the "next Virgin Mary" chosen by God. Initial blood tests including BUN, creatinine, electrolytes, and TSH, as well as an ECG, are all normal. After conducting the necessary evaluations, the decision is made to initiate her on lithium therapy. How long, with consistent dosing, will it take for the medication to reach a steady state in her system?
questions.solution:
Ans C) 5 days

 

Option C.

 

Lithium reaches a steady state in the body after about 5 half-lives. The half-life of lithium is approximately 24 hours in most adults, depending on kidney function. Therefore, with regular administration, it generally takes about:

 

1 half-life = 24 hours

 

5 half-lives = 5 x 24 = 120 hours or 5 days for lithium to reach steady state.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Less than 24 hours is too short for lithium to reach a steady state.

 

Option B. 4 days is close, but slightly less than the standard time for lithium to reach its steady state.

 

Option D. 2 to 3 weeks is a longer duration than required for lithium to reach a steady state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Half-life of Lithium is 24 hours. Lithium reaches a steady state in the body after approximately 5 days (or 5 half-lives) with regular administration. Hence serum lithium levels are obtained 5 days after initiation or dose adjustment of lithium. Lithium is excreted in urine (99%). 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 649.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with a history of bipolar disorder is seen in the outpatient psychiatric clinic for a medication review. She has been stabilized on carbamazepine for the past year. Now, she inquires about the potential side effects of her medication. Which of the following side effects that she mentions is a dose-dependent adverse effect of carbamazepine, rather than an idiosyncratic one?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Double vision.

 

Option B.

 

Carbamazepine can have both dose-dependent and idiosyncratic side effects. Double vision (diplopia) is a dose-dependent side effect of carbamazepine. This means that the likelihood and severity of this side effect increase with higher doses of the medication. 

 

The other listed side effects are considered idiosyncratic, meaning they can occur unpredictably and are not necessarily related to the dose:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Agranulocytosis: This is a rare but serious reduction in white blood cells that can occur with carbamazepine use. It is not dose-dependent and requires immediate medical attention if suspected.

 

Option C. Stevens-Johnson syndrome: This is a severe and potentially life-threatening skin reaction. This is an idiosyncratic reaction associated with carbamazepine, especially in individuals with the HLA-B*1502 allele.

 

Option D. Pancreatitis: Although a rare side effect, pancreatitis associated with carbamazepine is considered idiosyncratic and not dose-dependent.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Side effects of Carbamazepine:

 

 

Ref: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 265-266.
